2. Other Professionals

We occasionally instruct legal and other professionals outside of One Legal to provide technical and\nadvisory support in relation to the matters we handle, subject to them confirming their strict\nconfidentially to our satisfaction.

In order for us to manage the relationship between One Legal and such professionals, it will be
necessary for us to share with them, in writing and orally, information and documentation relating to
our clients. To ensure that we comply with the rules and principles governing solicitorsâ€™ professional
conduct, in particular the duty of confidentially owed by solicitors to their clients, this letter expressly
authorises us to disclose such information to such professionals.

In addition, as part of our auditing process to ensure the compliance of our services with the highest
standards, external independent auditors will chose files at random to assess our systems and
ensure the effective audit of our processes of supervision, matter management and product delivery.
Most of our clients welcome and encourage this independent review of our service.
3. Identity and disclosure requirements

Government regulations require us to obtain confirmation of your identity. It would be helpful,\ntherefore, if you could let us have sight of documentation confirming your name, such as a passport\nor driving licence, and also address, for example a copy of a recent utility bill.

You need to be aware we have responsibilities under money laundering legislation to make reports in
certain circumstances and that where this is required, we cannot be held responsible for any loss,
damage or delay resulting from compliance with such requirements.
4. Documents
It is important that you keep all documents which relate in any way to your case.

For present purposes, the term â€˜documentsâ€™ includes anything recorded, whether in permanent, semi-
permanent or electronic form, such as letters, contracts, receipts, diaries, computer records,
photographs, videos, and anything else of that kind.

Whilst we do not need to see all of those documents at this stage, such documents may have to be
produced in court proceedings, and a duty is owed to the court to ensure that documents are
preserved in case they are required. Any documents you subsequently obtain which relate to your
case should also be kept. Also, if you have any other property connected with your case in any way,
you should preserve that property until the case is concluded.

After completing our work for you, we are entitled to keep all papers and documents relating to your
case. The firm also keeps papers (except for any papers you ask to be returned to you) for no more
than 6 years and keeps the file on the understanding that the firm has authority to destroy it after 6
years from the conclusion date of your case.

If it becomes necessary to retrieve papers or documents from storage in relation to continuing or new
instructions to act on your behalf, we would not normally charge for such retrieval. However, the firm
will make a charge, based on time spent producing stored papers or documents to you or to another
person at your request, in other circumstances. We may also charge for reading correspondence or
other work necessary to comply with instructions given by you or on your behalf in this connection.
5. Communication and suggestions
We are confident of providing a high quality service.
\nWe do, of course, welcome any suggestions you might wish to make which you think could help to\nimprove our service.

If, at any time, you are not happy with the service you are receiving from the firm in the first instance,
please contact the person responsible for your work and they will do what they can to resolve the
problem promptly. You are valued client of the firm and we should like the opportunity to put matters
right if any problems do arise.
\nIf, however, we are not able to resolve matters to your satisfaction you should then contact

7. Your responsibilities to One Legal and the court

Your case may involve court proceedings. We have a professional duty to uphold the rule of law and\nadministration of justice. We must comply with our duties to the court even where there are conflicts\nwith our obligations to you. This means we must not:
\nWe must comply with court orders that put obligations on us and ensure that evidence relating to\nsensitive issues is not misused.

We shall from time to time request from you instructions on how you wish to proceed plus any
documents which support your case. You must provide me with those instructions and documents in
a timely manner. You must also attend appointments arranged for you. Failure to do so may result in
adverse costs orders, which you will have to pay personally.
8. Data protection
We use the information you provide primarily for the provision of legal services to you and for related\npurposes including:

(i) updating and enhancing client records
 (ii) analysis to help us manage our practice
 (iii) statutory returns
 (iv) legal and regulatory compliance

Our use of that information is subject to your instructions, the Data Protection Act 1998 and our duty
of confidentiality. Please note that our work for you may require us to give information to third parties
such as expert witnesses and other professional advisers. Under data protection legislation you have
a right of access to the personal data that we hold about you.
\nWe may from time to time send you information that we think might be of interest to you. If you do not\nwish to receive that information please notify our office, preferably in writing.
9. Equality and diversity
We are committed to promoting equality and diversity in all our dealings with clients, third parties\nand employees. Please contact us if you would like a copy of our equality and diversity policy.
